properties.field_incident_overview:
As of May 6, 2025, the Coronado National Forest has terminated their Temporary Occupancy and Use Area Order due to the Stronghold Fire. 

The fire is now 85% contained with no change in acreage; 2,138 acres. 

The Stronghold Fire started at approximately 11:30 am on Monday, April 28, near Sunsites-Pearce and 16 miles south of Cochise. It was fueled by high winds and drought stricken fuels throughout the duration of the initial attack period. Heavy aircraft was used at the start, including Single Engine Air Tankers and Large Air Tankers to slow the fire from spreading to nearby homes. One secondary structure was destroyed in the fire. Stronghold remains under investigation. 

 

For more information:  

Coronado National Forest Temporary Closure Order: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r03/coronado/alerts/stronghold-fire

All evacuation information will come from the Cochise County Sheriff's Office: https://www.facebook.com/CochiseSO

Arizona Department of Forestry and Fire Management on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/arizonaforestry

Arizona Department of Forestry and Fire Management on X: https://x.com/azstateforestry
properties.title: Stronghold Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Greer Fire started at approximately 11am on May 13, 2025 within Greer proper on the west side of County Road 1120. The wind-driven fire is pushing to the east/northeast along the ridges through grass and pinyon-juniper. The cause of the fire is under investigation.

Interactive Evacuation Map

ADOT highway/traffic information

Fire Restrictions

Forest Service Closure Order
properties.title: Greer Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: 2321 acres & 100% contained. Firefighters will continue to monitor the fire area.
properties.title: Winnemucca Mountain Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: The Bartlett Fire is in burned in grass and brush near Bartlett Peak, 60 Miles NW of Winnemucca, NV.
properties.title: Bartlett Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
On July 6, a human-caused fire was reported in Olympic National Forest near the Mt. Rose Trailhead along the Lake Cushman Corridor. The fire – named the Bear Gulch Fire – is burning on a steep, rocky slope north of Lake Cushman in the Olympic National Forest and near the Staircase area of Olympic National Park. 

Management of the Bear Gulch and Tunnel Creek fires will transfer to local fire units on October 11, 2025.

Falling debris across NF 2400 (FS 24) continues to be a primary hazard in the area. Due to this significant safety concern, NF Road 2400 is closed, including access to day use, trailheads and other sites beyond the closure point, at mile marker 10.5. This junction is where the pavement ends and the Forest Service Road into the Staircase area of Olympic National Park begins. Access to Mount Rose Residential Division 2, 3 and 4 remains open.

Updates for this incident will be communicated as notable events occur. 

Evacuation Orders: All evacuations in the Lake Cushman area have been lifted. Current evacuation information: https://www.facebook.com/masoncosheriff


Lake Usage: Access to Lake Cushman is now open to public use.

For updates regarding the Bear Gulch Fire, you can also visit the Olympic National Forest website at https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/olympic 
and follow www.facebook.com/beargulch2025/ on social media. Videos are available to those without Facebook accounts using that link.

Smoke Outlook: https://outlooks.airfire.org/outlook/e620ac47? 

Air Space Restrictions: There are no flight restrictions. The TFR was lifted 9/29/2025.

Fire Restrictions: Olympic National Park and Olympic National Forest have returned to standard campfire regulations on 10/07/25. Campers should use caution with any open flame and ensure fires are completely extinguished - cool to the touch - before leaving a site. Campers are required by law to stay with their campfire from start to finish.


Mason County lifted burn restrictions for recreational fires only Tuesday Sept. 30. Please note that while it is anticipated the restriction for Residential and Land Clearing burns will also be lifted soon, they remain in effect at this time. If you have any questions, feel free to contact the Fire Marshal at 360-427-9670, extension 309.

https://masoncountywa.gov/departments/community_development/fire_marshal/burn_restrictions.php
properties.title: Bear Gulch Fire

properties.field_incident_description: The Stoner Mesa Fire is OUT
properties.field_incident_overview:
The 2005 Stoner Mesa Fire burned along Stoner Creek and on Taylor Mesa. Fire behavior was extreme early in the incident due to the prolonged lack of moisture, low humidity levels, strong shifting winds and lots of available fuel. Heavy rainfall in late August and into September significantly reduced fire activity. The fire was called out December 3, 2025.

The Stoner Mesa Fire area closure has been rescinded. Dangerous conditions may persist from fire-weakened trees and dangerous conditions during heavy rain.
properties.title: Stoner Mesa Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Cloudrest Fire was reported on August 14, 2025, around 3:44 p.m., from the Alert West camera system. It is located approximately 15 miles north of Virginia City, MT. The fire is burning in thick subalpine fir timber with a heavy dead and downed fuel component. The cause of the fire was determined to be from a thunderstorm. The fire is burning at 8,000 feet in elevation.

On August 30, 2025, at 6 PM, Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 8 took over command of the Fire from Northern Rockies Complex Incident Management Team 6. September 8, 2025, at 7AM, NWCIMT transferred command of the fire to a local Type 3 Incident Management Team. The Type 3 Incident Management Team transferred command back to the local Ranger District fire staff on September 17, 2025.
properties.title: Cloudrest

properties.field_incident_description: The fire is burning in rugged terrain with heavy dead and down timber. Firefighters will continue to utilize both direct and indirect tactics to guide fire behavior toward natural barriers such as treeline scree fields and minimize threats to private property, communities, infrastructure, watersheds, and other critical assets. Access is difficult, as much of the fire is in a non-motorized wilderness area.
properties.field_incident_overview: The La Plata Fire was reported on August 17, 2025, at 5:46 p.m. The wildfire is located on the Pike-San Isabel National Forest Cimarron and Camanche Grasslands on the south side of Twin Lakes Reservoir approximately 4 miles southwest of Twin Lakes, Colorado.
properties.title: La Plata

properties.field_incident_overview: The Derby Fire was declared out on Dec. 5, 2025.
properties.title: Derby Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
Start Date: August 24, 2025 

Cause: Lightning 

Location: Sierra National Forest, Fresno County 

Acres Burned: 59,844 

Containment: 99% 

Personnel: 248

Hand Crews: 1

Dozers: 2

Engines: 2

Water Tenders: 1


10/18/25 FINAL UPDATE: 
This is the final update for the Garnet Fire unless significant activity occurs. Tulare County Type 3 IMT transferred command of the fire to the Sierra National Forest Type 3 IMT on 10/17/25 at 6:00 P.M.

Current Situation: 
Fire behavior remains minimal and has further decreased in activity from recent rain and snow fall. Firefighters will continue to patrol and assess hazard trees, snags and clogged culverts.

Safety: 
Motorists should be aware of large machinery moving to and from the fire perimeter on area roads, adding to congestion and potential intermittent closures at choke points and mid-slope grades.

Air Quality: 
Check local air quality at: airnow.gov/.

Forest Closure: 
The Sierra National Forest issued a reduced Forest Closure Order on October 6, 2025. This reduced closure order was coordinated with the Fresno County Sheriff’s Office, along with multiple local, state, and federal agency cooperators, to identify the minimum area necessary for the safety of firefighting resources and forest visitors. An FS-7700 form will be required to enter the closed portion of the forest. Contact the District Ranger’s Office at (559) 855-5355 to request the FS-7700 form. For a copy of the closure and map, please visit the Sierra National Forest website at: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/sierra/alerts/garnet-fire-closure-update-oct-6.
properties.title: Garnet Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Dillon Fire was detected August 25, 2025 in the area of Dillon Creek just west of the Klamath River about 16 miles north of Orleans, California. The fire quickly grew to more than 300 acres by evening with extreme fire behavior and long-range spotting. 

California Complex Incident Management Team 1 (CA-CIMT 1) assumed command of the Dillon Fire on August 29. 

California Complex Incident Management Team 6 (CA-CIMT 6) assumed command of the Dillon Fire on September 11. 

North Coast Interagency Incident Management Team Type 3 assumed command of the Dillon Fire on September 24. 

A local forest Type 4 team is currently in command of the Dillon Fire.
properties.title: Dillon Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Katy Creek Fire started on August 30, 2025, following lightning strikes in the Colville National Forest, northwest of Kettle Falls, Washington. Burning in steep, rocky terrain with heavy timber, the fire posed challenges for direct suppression and required extensive use of hand crews and aerial resources. Early growth reached several hundred acres within days, ultimately expanding to nearly 4,700 acres. The fire threatened nearby structures and prompted road closures and area restrictions to protect public safety. Fire behavior ranged from smoldering and creeping to isolated torching and spotting under dry, windy conditions. Containment steadily increased as crews conducted mop-up, firing operations, and hazard tree mitigation, with the fire reported at over 90 percent contained in late September. Managed in coordination with other regional incidents, the Katy Creek Fire highlighted both the difficulty of firefighting in rugged forest terrain and the effectiveness of coordinated interagency response.

Closures: Colville National Forest initially implemented a closure order for the Katy Creek Fire but reduced the size on Sept 23, 2025.  View the entire order and map on their website.

Evacuations: Ferry County Sheriff's Office lifted all evacuations on Sept 26, 2025. You can get futures alerts about emergencies and other important community news by signing up for the Ferry County Alert System. You will receive time-sensitive messages wherever you specify, such as your home, mobile, or business phones, email address, text messages, and more.
properties.title: Katy Creek

properties.field_incident_overview: On September 1, 2025, Snow Peak fire was reported in Ferry County, 19 miles west of Kettle Falls, WA. The fire is located in a remote area approximately 19 miles west of Kettle Falls, WA. The fire is burning in an inventoried roadless area with very difficult access by foot. Resources responding include crews, air attack, and helicopters. The Snow Peak cabin, a valuable recreation site in the alpine area NW of the fire, has been prepped with structure wrap and there have been past fuel treatments in the immediate vicinity of the cabin which significantly lowers the risk of impact.
properties.title: Snow Peak

properties.field_incident_overview:
Evacuations: Curry County Sheriff John Ward has removed all evacation levels for the Moon Complex. 

There is no camping, hiking or fishing from the bank on the Rogue River between Marial and Foster Bar. 

The Emergency Area and Road Closure for the Moon Complex has been lifted. Bear Camp Road has been reopened. Please travel with caution along this route, watch for fire-related hazards and crews working along the roadway. The Rogue River Trail remains closed from Marial to Foster Bar. 

On September 3, a lightning event on the Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest caused a number of fires in the vicinity of the Rogue River about 11 miles northeast of Agness, Oregon. Six of these made up the initial Moon Complex: the Backbone, Brushy, Pinnacle, Tate, Paradise, and Stair fires. As of September 8, Paradise, Stair, and Brushy fires burned into the perimeters of other fires. Tate Fire is fully contained at 26 acres. Suppression and repair work continue on the Backbone and Pinnacle fires. 

Fire Restrictions: Tuesday, October 16, 2025, The Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest decreased the Fire Danger Rating to LOW across all five Ranger Districts and removed Public Use Restrictions forest-wide as well as on the Wild & Scenic section of the Rogue River. To learn more, visit the forest website: https://www.fs.usda.gov/alerts/rogue-siskiyou/alerts-notices

Fire Repair: There has been no measurable growth on the fire for a while. Repair of fire line and roadways is the primary focus of resources engaged on the Moon Complex

Wild and Scenic Rogue River: Camping is not allowed at this time along the wild and scenic portion of the river. Please refer to Facebook page for the locations of rest break areas.
properties.title: Moon Complex

properties.field_incident_description:
The fires occurred in steep terrain with heavy fuel loading with little to no road access. Suppression tactics were based on several safety concerns, including a lack of ingress and egress options that would result in unacceptable medevac times. Decisions are heavily based on firefighter safety and resources at risk. Resources continue to assess for opportunities for direct and indirect options.
A Type 5 Incident Commander has taken command of the fires. There are currently no immediate concerns to private infrastructure. Smoke from the fires are visible along the Hwy 56 corridor.

A closure order is in effect for roads and trails in the vicinity of the fires.
properties.field_incident_overview:
On August 31st, a lightning storm ignited 31 fires across the Kootenai National Forest.  Firefighting resources, (engines and hand crew modules) responded to these fires throughout the evening of Aug 31st and in the morning on September 1st. 10 lightning fires were ignited on the Cabinet Ranger District including the Isabella, Moran, and Lost Girl Fires which started in the Cabinet Mountain Wilderness.  Kootenai Rappelers were inserted into the Lost Girl fire on the evening of the August 31st.  Active fire behavior combined with difficult access and extremely steep and cliffy terrain compromised the safety of firefighters during this initial suppression efforts and firefighters disengaged ground operation.  A Type 5 Incident Commander has taken command of the fires. There are currently no immediate concerns to private infrastructure. 

Isabella: Start Date: 09/01/2025; Size: 1,411 acres as of September 28, 2025

Lost Girl: Start Date: 08/31/2025; Size: 309acres as of September 28, 2025

Moran Fire: Start Date: 08/31/2025; Size: .2 acres as of September 6, 2025 -The fire has not shown any smoke or heat for several days

*Updates will be made with any significant changes in fire behavior or growth. Updates may not occur daily.
properties.field_title_and_unit: MTKNF Isabella and Lost Girl Fires
properties.title: Isabella and Lost Girl Fires

properties.field_incident_overview:
On September 6, 2025, USFS fire managers were able to assess a new fire start caused by lightning, named the Tunnel Creek Fire, located in a remote area of the Buckhorn Wilderness in Olympic National Forest.

The fire is roughly 10 miles west of Quilcene, Washington and 1.5 miles west of the Tunnel Creek Trailhead accessed from FS Road 2740.

Updates related to the Tunnel Creek Fire will be shared on the Bear Gulch Fire Inciweb page as they are being managed by the same team.
properties.title: Tunnel Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_description: The wildfire is located within the Chiricahua Wilderness, Douglas Ranger District. It is not threatening any structures at this time.
properties.field_incident_overview:
The fire area is characterized by substantial accumulations of snags and dead-and-down fuels—legacy
debris from the 2011 Horseshoe 2 fire. While these heavy fuels are present in abundance, they are not
currently driving fire behavior in a significant way. Instead, active burning is concentrated within the
needle cast layered throughout timber stringers, where fine fuels are promoting persistent surface fire
activity. Ground operations are further complicated by overgrown trails and thick vegetation, which
restrict access and reduce maneuverability for suppression crews. These conditions, combined with
elevated fuel loading and obstructed containment corridors, continue to pose considerable challenges to
control efforts and require adaptive strategies to improve containment success.
properties.title: Stanford Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: On Wednesday, November 5, 2025, a private landowner detected smoke south of Circleville, WV in Pendleton County. Pendleton County emergency personnel immediately contacted the USDA Forest Service who responded. This wildfire is being managed under unified command with the State of West Virginia and the USDA Forest Service, Monongahela National Forest.  Initial acreage was estimated at 50 acres, with active, wind driven fire. The fire is burning in an oak-hickory forest type, with very steep, mountainous terrain making ground access difficult. Safety of firefighters and the public are the top priorities.
properties.title: Woodside Fire
